description:
Sapovirus Hu/Nagoya/NGY-1/2012/JPN is a strain of the Sapovirus genus, which belongs to the Caliciviridae family. Sapoviruses are small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses that are known to cause acute gastroenteritis in humans and other mammals.

The Sapovirus Hu/Nagoya/NGY-1/2012/JPN strain was isolated from a human stool sample collected in Nagoya, Japan, in 2012. Genetic analysis of this strain has shown that it belongs to the genogroup GI of the Sapovirus genus, which is one of the major genogroups associated with human sapovirus infections.

Sapoviruses, including the Hu/Nagoya/NGY-1/2012/JPN strain, are primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, and they can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fever in infected individuals. The virus can be particularly problematic in healthcare settings, where it can spread rapidly among patients and staff.

Further research on the epidemiology, genetic diversity, and pathogenesis of the Sapovirus Hu/Nagoya/NGY-1/2012/JPN strain, as well as the development of effective prevention and control strategies, may contribute to a better understanding and management of sapovirus-related diseases.
